ai.summary: The Arran Coastal Way is a demanding 161.4 km coastal circuit around the Isle of Arran in Scotland. It traverses rugged sea cliffs, sandy beaches, moorland, and forests, with frequent elevation changes and exposed sections. As a hard long-distance route, it requires solid navigation, thorough preparation, and good weather judgment.
ai.terrain_summary: Expect mainly coastal paths and cliff-top tracks with rocky surfaces, mixed with forest trails and occasional roads. Terrain ranges from rough, uneven ground and wet, slippery sections to gentle coastal paths; long ascents near headlands and long, exposed coastlines demand stamina and careful footing. Be prepared for wind and sea spray.
ai.safety_notes: Weather on Scotland’s coast can change rapidly; carry appropriate clothing and protection. Some stretches are remote with limited phone signal—bring a map, compass, and GPS, and inform someone of your plan and daily targets. Pack adequate food, water, and a means to purify water if needed. Check tide times for any beach crossings and avoid exposed cliffs in bad conditions. Start early in winter and carry a reliable light source; let someone know if plans change.
recommended_gear: Weatherproof, breathable outer layer (jacket and pants)
Backpack with enough capacity (20–40 L depending on trip length)
Map and compass (and GPS as backup)
Fully charged phone with offline maps
Water bottle or hydration system (minimum 2 L)
First aid kit and personal medications
Dry bags or sealable bags for electronics
Knowledge of tide patterns or coastal weather apps
ai.best_seasons: April–October (spring to autumn) is generally best for daylight and more stable weather, though coastal conditions remain unpredictable; shoulder seasons can be misty or windy, while winter brings shorter days and harsher conditions.
